sense.name: (Cause to) become lusterless in appearance.
sense.commentary: Syntax Is: NP1[concrete] DULL NP1[agent] DULL NP2[patient[concrete]] NP1[theme] DULL NP2[patient[concrete]] Note: Compare to Sense 3; in Sense 1, NP2 must always be CONCRETE.
sense.examples: Age has dulled the surface of this table. You will dull bright colors if you wash them in hot water.

sense.name: Deaden a noise.
sense.commentary: My headphones dulled the sound of the baby screaming.

sense.name: (Cause to) become numb, insensitive or less intense
sense.commentary: Syntax Includes: NP1[theme[abstract]] DULL NP1[agent] DULL NP2[patient[abstract]] NP1[theme] DULL NP2[patient[abstract]] Note: Compare to Sense 1; in Sense 3, NP2 must always be ABSTRACT.
sense.examples: They dulled the joy of many pleasure-seekers yesterday. Canadian monetary policy has dulled the effect of changing exchange rates. The drugs have dulled the pain.

sense.name: (Cause to) become less sharp as a cutting instrument.
sense.commentary: Syntax Includes: NP1[theme] DULL NP1[agent] DULL NP2[patient[concrete]]
sense.examples: If you use scissors to cut tin foil, you'll dull them quickly. These knives have dulled with use.

sense.name: (Cause to) become less interesting, attractive or vigorous.
sense.commentary: Syntax Includes: NP1[theme[animate]] DULL NP1[theme] DULL NP2[patient[animate]]
sense.examples: You sure have dulled over the years. The monotonous assembly line job has really dulled Marty.
